comment.body: Maybe like Firefox OS and CyanogenMod have transformed into a community project (B2g OS, lineage OS), Ubuntu mobile will be the same.

@ulrichard: I don't use CyanogenMod too. Before I used a Blackberry Q10 (and you should know that Blackberry has officially discarded their own OS), I switched to Yotaphone 2 about half a year ago and I enjoy the eink screen very much. Back to the topic, I believe Ubuntu mobile developers and contributors won't give up their lovely kid. And I remember that Debian Community is [developping universal mobile system](https://wiki.debian.org/Mobile), this is very promising. And [this](https://wiki.debian.org/Mobile/Ubuntu) ;)
Don't know how to convert a whole nodejs app, but once I used [Webpack](https://webpack.github.io/) to convert npm lib, hope it helpful

@Nofish: Idea: Using hub as language filter.
Therefore at the beginning users are suggested to choose a hub by language (and interests, if some people like to create a specific group, like EN-anarchy, MULTI-multiculturism). Also users are able to view content from a specific hub (or local hub timeline). And it will be nice if users are easy to migrate to other hubs as s/he likes, and/or users can log in different hub using different ID.

The flagship is mastodon.social, maintained by main dev https://mastodon.social/@Gargron. The most active one I guess is mstdn.jp, so most japanese.
I guess there is no compeitition there, you can follow other people from any instances. Actually many devs dislike an instance with too many users, because it's not a good thing for decentralization.
Also I have a personal Gnusocial instance and I use it a lot. You can follow [me](https://social.binchan.xyz/chbinnc) if you join one :3

@Kaffie: They use the same protocol "OStatus", so it can be said that they are connected. Mastodon is developed by Ruby on Rails. Gnusocial is mainly developed by PHP and Javascript, and has been existing for a long time before Mastodon came out.

Added :) New version is available in [my blog](/1EiMAqhd6sMjPG2tznkkGXxhdwFBDdeqT9/?Post:3), [my gallery](/1ADGCZCvC6wCf5GwCY23H9uwKyRiixoLt6/dark/theme/2017/06/22/zeronet-dark-theme.html) and [git.gnu.io](https://git.gnu.io/chbinnc/Userscripts/raw/master/Userstyles/zeronet-dark-theme.userstyle.css)

Just tested it with my ZeroMessage widget, works very well! Before I searched a workaround online, and it scared me that all the solutions I saw needed jquery library. Finally I found [a bloated solution](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38738442/is-there-a-way-to-make-a-textbox-auto-expand-without-jquery) compare to yours. Thx.

Read the news from another source, just experimental now, but really fascinating. Also remind me of this one: [the U.S. Federal Communications Commission has, for the first time, given a company permission to build a next-generation satellite Internet service that promises to be both ultra-fast and affordable.](http://internethalloffame.org/blog/2017/07/28/one-step-closer-internet-everyone)

Jetzt gibt es [Hub timeline](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Post/1oranGeS2xsKZ4jVsu9SVttzgkYXu4k9v/1AWwhg4EiWAVttfQboJZ4wJfX3WawfJT3h/1503050901). Ich versuche Language Filter zu implementieren. Aber ich kann nicht sagen, wann es fertig sein wird.

@Krixano: @Nofish: Me too. My ZeroNet sometimes hangs up (can't open any site) and if I pause some ZeroMe hub updates, everything works again (some just took forever to update and finally failed, check files didn't work). Sometimes I just wait for several minutes until the ZeroMe hubs fail to update their files.

> The device will run the company's PureOS platform, a derivative of Debian GNU/Linux, but it will also be able to run most​​ GNU+Linux​​ distributions. And since Purism wants to give you as much control over the device as possible, it will release the device's source code, so you can edit it whenever you want.

Awesome!

What about also add a list the things one can or will be able to buy/pay with bitcoin? Recently I read a piece of news that a region of Switzerland will accept Bitcoin to pay tax (Steuer), that's impressive.

@Krixano: No luck. Looks like your net is still unable to pump it out...

@Krixano: Me too. Reload and rebuild the database do the trick. Maybe by comparing the databases before and after the rebuilding  you can find the bug, if the databases are the same, then it's probably a bug from ZeroNet itself.

From [Site development -> get started on ZeroDoc](https://zeronet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/site_development/getting_started/)
>To run ZeroNet in debug mode use: python zeronet.py --debug
>Debug mode features:
>
>    Automatic CoffeeScript -> JavaScript conversion (All examples used in this documentation and sample sites are written in CoffeeScript)

If Coffeescript 2.x has some compile errors, use a 1.x version instead.
@Krixano: For that it's necessary to understand the related part of src of ZeroNet. Hope someone is interested in taking that job :)

Thank Senpai! I can't add the zite too, can you publish it one more time? If possible, can you also use [a clearnet proxy](/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:proxies) to help seeding and checking if you zite is published?
@空澄砂夜: @Git Center: I'm seeding it now
@空澄砂夜: Hmm... You may shut down ZeroNet too early after publishing your repo, and there are still about 40 files failed to sync and the content is blank ><
Bitcoin surely has been big-banged, many cryptocurrency pioneers and hackers become the new millionaires, there are more flexible ways to make living, and so on
Merger site feature like Git Center so user can fully control his own content but still you and later other moderators can moderate the content by configuring ZeroMedium itself.

@Krixano: I think it's important, without such a feature, you need to take responsibility with every users' content, and if your private key of the zite is stolen, the stealer could modify users' content as they like. But I agree it's not urgent, so take your time.
@Git Center: Wow! There are tons of writing inside! Thank you very much!
